captions.text: Good morning Hank, it's Tuesday.

I was duly awed by your epic and encyclopedic
rant about punishments. And so, even though

I still believe in my heart that I do not
owe a punishment, I'm going to do one because

data does not lie. Well, sometimes it does,
but it lies less than your heart. That's what
today's video is kind of about, actually.

Okay, Hank, so my favorite character in this
summer's Book Club pick, "Behind the Beautiful

Forevers", is Sunil the twelve-year-old garbage
picker who grew up in an orphanage, in fact
we're told,

"Though Sunil was not an orphan, he understood
that phrases like 'AIDS orphan', and 'when

I was the second hand woman to Mother Teresa'
helped Sister Paulette, the nun who ran the

Handmaids of the Blessed Trinity Children's
Home, get money from foreigners."

By the way, little recommendation, when you
have a four-year-old child, don't take books
to the beach.

So anyway, that's the first mention of charity
in Behind the Beautiful Forevers, and boy,

is it complicated. Sunil is a non-orphan in
an orphanage, Sister Paulette lies to raise

money, and we later read that when the orphanage
collects clothes for the kids and then sells
those clothes to pay for other stuff.

But while Sunil isn't an orphan, he does need
the orphanage. Plus, he learns to read while

he's there. And that's the kind of non-straightforward
story about charities, both domestic and international,

that we rarely hear, especially from charities
themselves.

Right, because they have to raise money, and
telling people,

"Ah, we think this is going to go well, it
isn't going to be perfect, but we suspect

it will be a net-positive, although there's
no way to know", that's a terrible fundraising
strategy.

But that's closer to the reality that we see
in Behind the Beautiful Forevers, like the

charity-administered school in Annawadi is
taught by a teenager and definitely sub-standard.

And toward the end of the book we learn that
many charity-administered schools are outright

frauds. When a new school opened in the Pink
Temple by the sewage lake, many children gravitated

to it. But it closed as soon as the leader
of the non-profit had taken enough pictures

of children studying to secure government
funds.

And then there are, like, collaborations between
government and charity, which are also sometimes

problematic. Like, you'll remember that Annawadi's
political representative who is super corrupt

keeps getting public amenities, care of the
charity World Vision. You know, like public

toilets and gutters etcetera, and that's all
good stuff, but it's timed to the elections
so that he can keep his power.

And so you could see it as these projects
like further institutionalizing the corrupt

power system, right. But then again, good
toilets are really important for public health.
It's complicated.

Hank, this is all particularly interesting
to me right now because, as you watch this,

I am in East Africa learning about some of
the work that people there are doing with
the help of the Gates Foundation.

Now, the situation in East Africa is vastly
different from the situation in Annawadi,

but around the world, including in our own
neighborhoods, we need to look at what charities
do and how well they do it.

Hank, you don't want to be giving to charity
simply because it makes you feel good or because

it lessens some guilt that you have. We want
to actually decrease World Suck. I apologize

for splitting that infinitive but I felt that
it was necessary.

When we talk about health and poverty, we
are talking about incredibly complicated problems

and yes, money can be misallocated, and it
can be used to bolster corrupt regimes, but

we have lots of data -- links in the doobly-doo
-- showing that in the last twenty years,

when people have access to the right resources
and tools, they can transform the health and
economic opportunities in their communities.

Rising income, better food security, higher
literacy rates, lower infant mortality -- those
aren't anecdotes and they are real progress.

Hank, one of the reasons I continue to reread
"Behind the Beautiful Forevers" is that it

doesn't contain any unambiguous victories.
Not for the characters, certainly, but also

not for foreign aid or government spending
or microfinance or charity. Non-profit spending

doesn't always work, partly because not all
non-profits are equally effective and partly
because no one succeeds all of the time.

I think when trying to figure out what does
work, data is probably ultimately a better

guide than anecdote. But then again, data
can also be manipulated. Hank, we are either

going to embrace complexity or we're going
to be lying to ourselves. That's what I took

away from "Behind the Beautiful Forevers".
I look forward to reading your thoughts in
comments when I return.

Hank, I hope to learn a lot this week, and
I hope to listen a lot, but if I come home

with straightforward answers and simple solutions,
I am probably doing it wrong.

Okay Hank, although I will be very jet-lagged,
I will see you on Friday.

title: Ambiguous Victories and Real Progress: Behind the Beautiful Forevers

comments.text:
Behind the Beautiful Forevers is the best non-fiction book I have read. I 
felt like it didn't really finish, but I guess that's because the people 
that survived the book are still living and carrying on with life in 
Annawadi. I read it like fiction the whole way through, and when I got to 
the end and was reminded of its non-fictionness, I just kind of sat in 
astonishment for a long while because the events it depicts seem completely 
surreal.﻿
comments.author: Julia Douglas

comments.text:
I bought the book and read it. I didn't read any front matter. I didn't 
read reviews. As a result, I read the whole thing as a work of fiction (i'd 
contend the voice in which the book is written contributed to this.) Only 
realising my mistake after I'd read it all.

It is an unusual feeling, to read about characters fictionally being 
tortured and later realise that the characters were people, the torture 
actual, and your relative indifference really inappropriate.﻿

comments.text:
I found Behind the Beautiful Forevers to be a fascinating character study 
as well. It's tempting (and simpler) to classify people and say this is 
what slumdwellers are like, this is what Indians are like, this is what I 
am like... But the truth is more complicated. Boo presents real people, 
full of faults and failings and hopes and questions. Many (all?) of them 
were trying to do the best they could with what they had. It made me take a 
closer look at myself.﻿

comments.author: yolanda ramirez

comments.text:
It was a difficult book for me to get through, not because it was written 
poorly or the content boring, but because of the sadness I felt for each of 
the characters. The saddest part to me was that many Annawadians felt they 
were economically better off than they once had been. Take Asha, for 
example, when she returned to her home village she felt more privileged 
than the people she grew up with. But by the end of the book she was still 
one of the poorest people in the city and living with an alcoholic husband. 

Unambiguous victories... I think in the book all the characters experience 
various ambiguous victories, ones they themselves probably wouldn't even 
categorize as victories. The unambiguous victory of economic freedom is the 
only victory they care about though, and in that way none of them win. ﻿
comments.author: Emily Coulter

comments.text: My name is Charity﻿
comments.author: Charity LaFrance

comments.text:
Behind The Beautiful Forevers also got me thinking about charity, but about 
education as well. Because I work with academics, the Indians I usually 
meet are the ones who had to achieve near-perfect marks in high school to 
be able get one of the coveted university places, or who had to go to 
abroad at age 18 to study at a foreign university. There already is such a 
shortage of higher education spots. Increasing elementary level and high 
school education is clearly necessary for people to be able to get proper 
jobs, but improving it at that level would then cause even more strain on 
the university system. Solving one problem creates problems somewhere else. 
I think that was the main thing I took home from the book in general!

(Also, it's embarrassing how long it took me to figure out that the title 
refers to the row of "Beautiful Forever" ads on the wall around Annawadi. 
Or the airport wall, I forgot which one.)﻿

comments.text:
I think it's quite a happy coincidence that this was the chosen book club 
reading this summer, as it is also a required reading for my summer AP 
English Language classwork. I'm supposed to find examples of how the 
English language is showcased in Boo's observational tale, but I can't help 
but become entangled in the themes that you pointed out in the video. It's 
hard to focus on the style of the words when I'm so intent on absorbing 
their meaning. ﻿
comments.author: Charlotte Pierce

comments.text:
I liked the complexity of the story but also that of the language and tone. 
I could feel that the author is invested but does not want to infuse to 
much subjectivity to the story. I loved the deep way in which it is shown 
that so much is circumstantial (the trial scenes represent the epitome of 
randomness). I sensed the authenticity of the characters and liked how the 
juxtaposition of their fates was literary brought forward to show that we 
can influence each other lives even if we do not know about each other. ﻿
comments.author: devilskinn

comments.text:
Sunil is my favourite character too. I like the way he tries to understand 
the world and himself in it, a quest I am also currently on. This actually 
shows that I am a selfish reader because most of the times I see the 
individual picture, the way I can internalize the lessons or struggles of 
the characters, how the theme affects me personally, and only secondarily 
arrive to the global scope. Not that these can be split. I am well aware of 
the intertwining of these two levels with one another and with other, many 
more, levels. It is indeed a good feature about this book, that it neither 
sugar-coats the story, nor dramatizes it. (Note to self: Some things go 
amiss, do them differently. Or do something else, just get involved in life 
inside and outside your head, the best you can). The characters are 
incredibly realistic and relatable, which, given their exogenous 
circumstances, makes it all the more fascinating.
I love some quotes from the book, but the one that really stuck and left me 
staring at the ceiling for several minutes, ruminating, is the next, about 
Sunil:
"But something he'd come to realize on the roof, leaning out, thinking 
about what would happen if he leaned to far, was that a boy's life could 
still matter to himself." 
PS. Thank you, John, for setting up the book club! I like it a lot, even 
though I join in the discussions quite infrequently.﻿
comments.author: devilskinn

comments.text:
I think there is no such thing as an unambiguous victory- when one entity 
comes out on top there always has to be someone else that got the shorter 
end of the stick. To gain ground is also to hold back others who also 
wanted to gain that ground.﻿

comments.author: Bacon36025

comments.text:
Since you are currently in East Africa, I thought you might be interested 
in reading the book What is the What by Dave Eggers, which takes place in 
East Africa, including Ethiopia. It is a phenomenal book that I get to read 
for school. It is a biography of a Lost Boy from Sudan. This novel depicts 
surreal events so sometimes, to me a 15 year old, it is hard to believe 
that it actually happened to someone. The beauty of What is the What is 
that is displays the same emotions that I have felt, but in a completely 
different situation. It reminds me that Valentino, the main character, was 
just a kid like me when he ran away from the war. What is the What is 
empowering and is a work of art. I would absolutely recommend this book to 
everyone and anyone. Perhaps this will the next book the nerdfighters read! 
Hope you have a very humbly and eyeopening experience in East Africa. ﻿

comments.text:
I loved this book! I love the truth about the lives the people of Annawadi 
lead. It shows how things such as donating to charities are not always how 
it seems. I have this new curiosity about India now. In school we are 
always taught the same things about the same cultures (at least in my 
experience). This book is truly a book that changed my perception of the 
world. I am now motivated to try to help people in bad situations 
throughout my life. Although I live a very different life from the people 
in Behind the Beautiful Forevers, I still try to understand them and 
realize that humans aren't all that different.﻿

comments.author: Sarah Elizabeth

comments.text:
Dear John:
You're an accomplished, published writer.  Why the balls do you care about 
stupid arbitrary "grammatical" rules like splitting infinitives or ending 
sentences with prepositions?  Neither of those has anything to do with 
English, they're prescriptive rules based on the thought that since you 
/can't/ split an infinitive in Latin (because infinitives in Latin are one 
word with a modified suffix), then you /shouldn't/ do it in English - 
probably because of some nonsense about Latin being a 
better/purer/holier/smarter language than English.  Which is ridiculous, 
because no language is inherently better than any other.

I feel like you do actually know better, since you just did it in this 
video; you just excused it because you "felt that it was necessary."  So 
why should you ever avoid it?  The only possible reason would be if it 
sounds better when you don't, and that's the only reason.  If it ever feels 
necessary, then do it: avoiding it almost always just sounds more awkward.

Native speakers of English cannot speak their language incorrectly because 
the language belongs to the people using it /as they use it/ in almost 
exactly the same way that books belong to their readers.  You can use the 
wrong vocabulary, you can make small mistakes, and you can certainly use 
the wrong register (because using informal slang in a formal setting is 
still wrong), but the fundamental grammar describing how English is spoken 
cannot and should not be prescribed.

Sincerely:
A fan with an English degree﻿
comments.author: Rhyno D

comments.text:
There's a common practice in Chinese cities that I thought of when I read 
the part about the dying scavenger with the crushed leg. 

Migrant workers from the countryside who can't find work fake fainting 
spells in the middle of busy intersections. They hope that if they get hit, 
the party responsible will have to pay a settlement and they'll have money 
to send back home. More disturbingly, elderly people often fake collapses 
in the streets, and they accuse the first person that helps them up of 
causing the collapse.

Consequently, when someone falls, everyone gathers around and stares. No 
one dares help for fear that they'll be accused.

Elderly people with existing medical conditions have taken to wearing a 
sign around their neck promising that anyone who helps in the case of 
emergency will not be blamed for the incident.﻿
comments.author: path0mango

Omg, you talk too fast:( i can not understand everything you say, i'm

comments.author: _bey0urself

comments.text:
As a linguistics student I'm compulsively compelled to say that splitting 
infinitives is not a thing. Some stuck up stuffed shirt in the 18th or 19th 
century arbitrarily decided to put it as a rule in his English grammar 
because he felt that English didn't look enough like Latin (which of course 
is just a much better language), and so he made up several "rules" to try 
to make English follow Latin grammar. Things which have absolutely nothing 
to do with English. He said you can't split an infinitive because in Latin 
any infinitive is all one word, and therefore impossible to split. This 
isn't the case in English, and so we've always felt free to split it as 
long as we have had the to+infinitive structure.﻿
comments.author: Hansen Lyman

comments.text: Lol. Fifty Shades of Grey before Johm Green. Phwoar.﻿
comments.author: Janet Graham-Russell

comments.text:
We do have to be very careful on charities.  "Foundations" are like the 
thing wealthy people make to say they're helping now but never check if 
they actually are.  Anyone with a few million can set one up and pretend 
they're doing something to help someone rather than just paying a friend to 
mismanage a bunch of money.
In recent years a lot more talk has happened about a lot of charity groups, 
and how some aren't really non-profits, but for-profit businesses that do 
their best to appear as charities.  Even some of what people would think to 
be as great charities like the Red-Cross have been shown to spend gross 
amounts of money in the name of "getting people to donate."  Now I'm not a 
money manager, but if you're spending several million to get the same 
people that donated several million last year to do so again rather than 
just having them keep doing it because they get tax benefits for doing it 
in the first place, I question what the real purpose of that money spent 
is.  There is also Salvation Army who have come under fire for practices 
they conduct about their employment, specifically about people of different 
sexualities.  It's doubly sad because currently they are the charity that 
gives the absolute most, dollar per dollar, back into actual charities and 
not into their own pockets.
And while I would like to stop there I do have to bring up about internet 
activists and the entire problem they pose.  Much like many of these big 
"donate to feel good" situations you're getting singular people trying to 
convince you if you give them money they can solve a major problem in the 
world.  One of these was the infamous Kony2012 drive, in which 
misinformation told you nothing about how Kony was off in another region 
now and not even confirm alive.  Rather he wanted you to buy all sorts of 
things for him because it would "help."  Not too long ago an "internet 
activist" told everyone she was going to tell everyone why video games were 
evil and such.  Not only did she start out by promising what her findings 
would be before the study even began, but she fell through on promises of 
even just increasing video quality and people began to point out all her 
game captures came from various youtuber's videos, not through her 
conducting any research.  Unfortionally she has supporters that are more 
devout to her than spanish inquisitors, so even if you somehow found out 
she spent the money on everything but doing any research, they'd still 
follow her unquestioningly and attack anyone that has even slight doubt in 
her strawman arguments.

I think that's a large enough bloated comment from me...﻿

comments.author: Lee Murdock

comments.text:
I went to Sierra Leon for a month and found the same thing. There is such a 
thing as "Toxic Aid". What I mean is exactly what you are talking about, 
people there after the civil war in the 90s (see Blood Diamond with Leo 
DiCaprio) people rushed to give them aid. I think that is a good thing, but 
what I found interesting was that the aid never transferred from immediate 
care aid (clothes, food, temp. shelter, etc.) to long term aid (sewage, 
roads, sustainable food, etc.), and a broken economy sprung up from it. 
People take clothes and bottled water that is sent over and sell it, it's 
normal and integral part of their economy. The entire culture has morphed 
around rich white people coming in and giving them money, they even have 
words that basically mean "White sugar daddy". The tough part is that we 
can't pull the funding either and just say "stand up!" because of all of 
the hurt it would cause. It's a sticky situation, and our fault as the 
better off is (as usual) ignorance. Blindly throwing money at something 
only partially fixes problems, we have to pay attention and actually look 
and THINK about what we are doing to be effective at solving needs...

TL: DR Think about how you give aid, money and water bottles sounds 
awesome, but is not as effective as farming implements and water filters.﻿
comments.author: Brandon Admire

comments.text:

and is what most books lack.﻿
comments.author: Oren Colins

comments.text:
My thoughts after reading the book are about the ethical responsibilities 
of journalists. Is it really okay for a foreign journalist (or any 
journalist) to profit from the stories and lives of marginalized people. 
Did Katherine Boo pay her informants for their information? Did she try to 
help ease their suffering in any way? I think it is the moral obligation of 
journalists to help those who they write about, especially if they spent 
significant time living with the people. I would like more information 
about Katherine Boo's methods and how the people whose lives we read about 
were compensated for sharing their stories.﻿
comments.author: nordie111

comments.text:
Every year or so, Northeastern University runs this awesome free online 
course, Giving with Purpose! It is all about determining which charities 
are worth investing in, and what makes for a well-run nonprofit. Even 
cooler - you get to help decide where real money (thousands of dollars!) is 
donated to! Check out the intro video here: 
http://www.northeastern.edu/ns4g/giving-with-purpose/﻿

Okay so I'm sorry if this gets annoying because I'm going to post this in a 
lot of places so that it's more likely you see it but: I'm Autumn. I'm 14 
years old. I live in Houston, Texas. I would like to be you for Halloween. 
I don't care if I'm a girl. I would vlog while dressed up like you, but I 
don't know what I would wear. I have some ideas but I am curious to how YOU 
want me to portray you. Is there anything specific you would want me to 
wear or have on my person? I think you are an awesome person and am so very 
excited to get to be you for a night. Thank you for being you and please 
let me know how you think I should dress up. ~Autumn﻿
comments.author: Autumn Riley

comments.text:
Okay so first off, I'm an Indian living in America so I do believe that I 
have a more of wider perspective then you John (No offense) I am going to 
give the cold hard truth here, Im not going to sugarcoat it and Ill likely 
write an essay (sorry) 
I visit India pretty often, I go to visit my grandparents in New Delhi 
which is incredibly populated with poor people. I see them all the time 
begging on the streets. I see cripples begging for money. I see pregnant 
woman. I see women with injured children praying for money to raise their 
child. Everybody on the streets has a sob story to tell but all of these 
sob stories are lies. I remember the first time I saw a begger, or at least 
the first time I remember noticing one. He was a little boy around my age 
of the time and he knocked on our car window asking for money. He looked so 
pathetic with ragged clothes and a limp my heart just went out for him.I 
started pleading with my parents to give him money (stupidly in English and 
he realized we were foreigners so he became mpre insistent) My parents told 
me to look away and they asked me if one should give a poor man fish or 
teach a poor man how to fish. I was confused and they explained to me that 
you cant just give money to the poor esp in India cause it doesnt really 
help anybody.
When I got older they told me more atrocious stories although they still 
shaded me from seeing some of the truly grotesque affects of these stories. 
People will do anything for money they told me. My parents told true 
examples of men who purposely crippled children because they can beg for 
more money then a noncripple.They told me of a true example for people 
stealing babies and injuring them/killing them because hurt babies make 
more revenue. I was 13 when I saw a woman carrying a baby. The baby's head 
was bashed in and it was bleeding. I suppose it was dead. I only got a 
glimpse of the image before my mom pulled me into her. Its been a good 
three years and I still cant get the image out of my head.
Anyways the point is that in India there are the truly hopeless and lost 
but there are also deceitful people who do anything for money. How are you 
supposed to tell one from the other? You cant. You cant give money to 
charities either because they dont tell the truth about what they really do 
with it. India is built on corruption which is really really sad because 
the culture and Hinduism is really deep and colorful and India could do so 
well but the people are so bad....I love India, but I only love what India 
was and I only love what it is in the books.
Okay Im done for now...expect another rant from me when you post the next 
BTBF video...﻿
comments.author: Tanvi Kataria

comments.author: Olivia VanArsdale

comments.text:
I was fascinated that the characters in the book are real people, with real 
stories.  I was impressed that Boo could make them seem like characters in 
a novel.  But I suppose that's why their stories don't have concrete 
endings- they're still living, and while many of us can whip up a funny 
anecdote from something that happened at the store or at work, our lives 
don't necessarily follow a literary arc.﻿

Wrong". In it is points out that the data you’re looking at to pick a 
charity is probably the wrong criteria if you want a world where the great 
social issues can be tackled by non-profits. 
http://www.ted.com/talks/dan_pallotta_the_way_we_think_about_charity_is_dead_wrong
